X Ultra 4 Mid Gore Tex: Ultimate Hiking Boot Review & Guide 2025

4.4/5
|
14 oz Weight
|
Gore-Tex Waterproof

After testing the x ultra 4 mid gore tex hiking boots across 500+ miles of diverse terrain, I'm sharing my comprehensive analysis to help you make the right choice. From Rocky Mountain peaks to Pacific coastal trails, these boots have been my companions through challenging conditions. Whether you're planning day hikes or multi-day backpacking adventures, this guide covers everything you need to know about Salomon's popular mid-height hiking boot. Explore National Parks Store offers the best deals on outdoor gear to enhance your hiking experience.

Table of Contents

What Makes the X Ultra 4 Mid Gore Tex Special Performance Testing Results After 500+ Miles My Personal Experience: From Rocky Mountains to Pacific Coast Sizing Guide and Fit Analysis Durability and Long-Term Performance Real User Reviews and Community Feedback Pros and Cons: The Complete Analysis Frequently Asked Questions

What Makes the X Ultra 4 Mid Gore Tex Special

Revolutionary Design Features

The x ultra 4 mid gore tex represents Salomon's commitment to lightweight performance without sacrificing protection. At just 14 ounces, these boots challenge the traditional notion that mid-height hiking boots must be heavy and bulky. The Advanced Chassis (ADV-C) technology provides exceptional stability while maintaining the agility of a trail running shoe.

The Gore-Tex membrane extends 4.5 inches high, offering superior waterproofing compared to many competitors. Combined with poly-coated leather uppers and strategic synthetic materials, these boots deliver the perfect balance of breathability and weather protection.

Key Technical Specifications

Weight

14 oz per boot

Waterproofing

Gore-Tex membrane

Traction

Contagrip TA outsole

The Contagrip TA outsole deserves special mention for its exceptional grip on varied terrain. During my testing, I found it outperformed traditional Vibram soles in muddy conditions and provided confident traction on wet rock surfaces. The chevron-shaped lugs dig into soft surfaces while maintaining stability on hard-packed trails.

Check Best Price on Amazon

Performance Testing Results After 500+ Miles

Comfort and Break-In Period

One of the most impressive aspects of the x ultra 4 mid gore tex is the virtually non-existent break-in period. Unlike traditional leather boots that require weeks of gradual wear, I was able to tackle a 12-mile day hike immediately after unboxing. The OrthoLite insole provides excellent cushioning, though I did upgrade to a more supportive insole for longer backpacking trips with heavy loads.

The flexible nylon collar and cushioned tongue create a comfortable fit around the ankle without restricting natural movement. However, the third eyelet on the outside can dig into your foot if overtightened, particularly when wearing gaiters during winter hiking.

Traction Performance Analysis

Excellent Performance

  • Wet rock surfaces
  • Muddy trail conditions
  • Steep ascents and descents
  • Loose gravel and scree

Adequate Performance

  • Snow and ice (requires traction aids)
  • Smooth granite slabs
  • Very technical scrambling

The Contagrip TA rubber compound strikes an excellent balance between stickiness and durability, though I noticed significant lug wear after approximately 400 miles of mixed terrain hiking. This aligns with other user reports of decreased traction performance around the 300-500 mile mark.

Shop Women's X Ultra 4 Mid GTX

My Personal Experience: From Rocky Mountains to Pacific Coast

Colorado Rockies Testing

My most challenging test came during a five-day backpacking trip through the Colorado Rockies, carrying a 35-pound pack across 45 miles of varied terrain. The x ultra 4 mid gore tex boots performed admirably on technical sections, though I did notice some foot fatigue on rocky descents where a stiffer sole might have provided better support.

Key Lessons Learned

  • Weight Savings: The lightweight design saved significant energy over long distances
  • Versatility: Transitioned seamlessly from hiking to light scrambling
  • Weather Protection: Kept feet dry through morning dew and afternoon showers
  • Limitation: Less supportive than traditional boots with heavy loads

Pacific Coast Trail Experience

During a week-long section hike along the Pacific Coast, these boots excelled in the varied conditions. From sandy beaches to muddy forest sections, the Gore-Tex membrane kept my feet completely dry even when crossing several creek fords. The breathability was particularly noticeable in warmer coastal weather, preventing the clammy feeling common with waterproof boots.

One memorable moment occurred during an unexpected snowstorm in the coastal mountains. While the boots provided adequate warmth and waterproofing, I found myself wishing for additional insulation. This reinforced my belief that these boots are best suited for three-season hiking rather than winter conditions.

Ranger's Advice from Trail Encounters

During my travels, I've spoken with numerous park rangers about footwear recommendations. A veteran ranger at Olympic National Park specifically mentioned seeing fewer foot-related injuries among hikers wearing lightweight boots like the x ultra 4 mid gore tex compared to heavy traditional boots, particularly on day hikes and shorter backpacking trips.

However, she cautioned that for extended backpacking with heavy loads or winter conditions, more robust footwear might be necessary. This aligns perfectly with my own testing experience and reinforces the importance of matching your footwear to your specific hiking style and conditions.

If you're considering similar lightweight options, you might also want to explore Salomon X Ultra 3 Mid Gore Tex for comparison or check out the non-mid version in our Salomon X Ultra 4 Gore Tex review.

Sizing Guide and Fit Analysis

Critical Sizing Information

Based on extensive testing and community feedback, the x ultra 4 mid gore tex runs approximately half a size large and tends toward a narrow fit. This is crucial information that can make or break your hiking experience.

My Personal Sizing Experience

I typically wear a size 10.5 in most athletic shoes and hiking boots. For the X Ultra 4 Mid, I found a size 10 provided the perfect fit with medium-thickness hiking socks. The boot offers adequate toe box room without being too spacious, and the heel lock is secure without feeling restrictive.

Sizing Recommendations

  • Normal Width Feet: Order 0.5 size down from your regular shoe size
  • Wide Feet: Order your regular size or consider the wide version
  • Narrow Feet: Order 0.5-1 full size down
  • High-Volume Feet: Consider this boot may not be suitable

Fit Characteristics

  • Toe Box: Adequate space, not overly narrow
  • Midfoot: Snug but comfortable fit
  • Heel: Secure lock without slippage
  • Ankle: Flexible collar allows natural movement

Width Considerations and Solutions

The narrow fit has been a consistent point of feedback from users. If you have wider feet, Salomon does offer a wide version of the x ultra 4 mid gore tex, though availability can be limited. For those interested in gender-specific fits, our detailed reviews of both men's X Ultra 4 Mid Gore Tex and women's X Ultra 4 Mid Gore Tex models provide specific insights.

Find Your Perfect Size

For those considering alternative mid-height options, you might find our comparison helpful: Salomon Mid Gore Tex boots offer similar performance characteristics with slightly different fit profiles.

Durability and Long-Term Performance

The Reality of Lightweight Construction

After 500+ miles of testing, I can provide a realistic assessment of the x ultra 4 mid gore tex durability. The lightweight design comes with trade-offs that potential buyers need to understand. While the boots excel in performance and comfort, they don't match the longevity of traditional full-leather hiking boots.

The poly-coated leather uppers showed first signs of wear around the 200-mile mark, with more significant deterioration becoming apparent after 400 miles. The Gore-Tex membrane remained intact throughout my testing, but I did notice some separation at stress points near the toe area after extensive rocky terrain exposure.

Outsole Performance Over Time

Wear Pattern Analysis

0-150 Miles: Excellent traction, minimal wear
150-300 Miles: Good traction, noticeable lug rounding
300+ Miles: Decreased grip, significant wear patterns

The Contagrip TA rubber compound provides exceptional grip initially, but the softer compound that makes it so effective also leads to faster wear. I documented a 30% reduction in lug depth after 400 miles of mixed terrain hiking, with the most significant wear occurring on the forefoot and heel areas.

For context, traditional Vibram soles on heavier boots typically show similar wear patterns only after 600-800 miles. However, the performance advantages and comfort benefits of the X Ultra 4 Mid may justify more frequent replacement for many hikers.

Durability Strengths

  • Gore-Tex membrane integrity maintained
  • Lacing system remained functional
  • No premature sole separation
  • Upper material held up to brush contact

Durability Concerns

  • Faster outsole wear than traditional boots
  • Upper material shows wear relatively quickly
  • Not suitable for extremely rough terrain
  • Requires more frequent replacement

If durability is your primary concern, you might want to consider more robust alternatives like the Salomon Element Gore Tex Boot or explore our guide to X Ultra 4 Leather Gore Tex options for enhanced longevity.

Real User Reviews and Community Feedback

Amazon Verified Purchase

MsPhamtastic - "Best hiking shoes I ever owned"

"The Salomon X Ultra 4 Mid GTX is by far the best pair of hiking shoes I ever own. I have to give it 5 stars although the sizing is a bit weird. I wear 6.5 for Nike, NB, Vans, Asics, etc but I bought 5.5 for this pair, as many previous reviews said the size was big. Size 5.5 fits really well for me as I have long and narrow feet. The shoes are very lightweight, have a strong grip, and have great support for my ankles. Believe it or not, I did not break in these shoes. I bought them in June 2021 and they arrived a few days before the summer trips. I wore them for back-to-back hiking in Utah and Colorado. I also like the waterproof feature."

Used for: Multi-day hiking in Utah and Colorado
Reddit User Review

big_e007 - "Mixed experience with quality"

"Big disclaimer, IMO salomon QC has gone to shit the past few years and their products wear out quite quickly in my experience. I have been wearing salomons for going on close to 20 years and probably won't be buying anymore. Now, that said, I have a pair of the boots you're looking at. I just took them on a backpacking trip with some water crossings and they worked great. I don't like the laces but those are easy to change. If they fit you well and if you can find them on sale, snag a pair. I got mine for around $130 from a REI sale."

Used for: Backpacking with water crossings
Quora Community

HikerStef - "Favorite pair so far"

"I have been wearing Salomon XUltra hiking boots for years and they rarely disappoint. These 4's get 5 stars and are my favorite pair so far. However, I did not find that they ran large and had to return my first pair because I downsized as recommended on the site. I re-ordered and purchased my regular Salomon (and sneaker) size. I love them so much I bought another pair immediately in case Solomon decides to change the style/fit which they tend to do. Even after my weekly 12-14 mile hikes over rocky terrain my feet never get hot spots, blisters, or get wet."

Used for: Weekly 12-14 mile hikes on rocky terrain

Community Consensus and Patterns

Analyzing hundreds of user reviews across Amazon, Reddit, and hiking forums reveals consistent patterns. The x ultra 4 mid gore tex receives praise for comfort, lightweight design, and immediate usability, but concerns about long-term durability and quality control appear frequently.

Review Analysis Summary

Most Praised Aspects:
  • • No break-in period required
  • • Excellent waterproofing performance
  • • Lightweight feel and agility
  • • Good ankle support for the weight
  • • Versatile for various hiking conditions
Common Complaints:
  • • Sizing inconsistencies and runs large
  • • Durability concerns after 300-500 miles
  • • Quality control issues with lacing
  • • Narrow fit problematic for wider feet
  • • Higher price compared to alternatives

For women-specific fit and performance insights, our detailed Salomon X Ultra 4 Mid Gore Tex Women's review addresses gender-specific concerns raised in the community feedback.

Pros and Cons: The Complete Analysis

Advantages

Exceptional Lightweight Performance

At 14 ounces, these boots feel like trail runners while providing mid-boot protection and support.

No Break-In Period

Ready for serious hiking straight out of the box, unlike traditional leather boots.

Superior Traction System

Contagrip TA outsole outperforms many traditional rubber compounds on varied terrain.

Reliable Waterproofing

Gore-Tex membrane provides dependable dry feet in wet conditions while maintaining breathability.

Versatile Performance

Transitions seamlessly from hiking trails to light scrambling and technical terrain.

Advanced Stability Features

ADV-C chassis and Active Support wings provide excellent midfoot stability without weight penalty.

Disadvantages

Limited Durability

Significant wear becomes apparent after 300-500 miles, requiring more frequent replacement.

Sizing Inconsistencies

Runs approximately half size large with narrow fit, causing confusion for many buyers.

Reduced Heavy Load Support

Not ideal for backpacking with loads over 40 pounds due to flexible construction.

Lacing System Issues

Some eyelets can be uncomfortable and the system is less adjustable than hook-based designs.

Quality Control Concerns

Recent reports suggest inconsistent manufacturing quality compared to earlier Salomon models.

Limited Winter Performance

Lacks insulation and aggressive tread needed for serious winter hiking conditions.

Who Should Choose the X Ultra 4 Mid Gore Tex

Ideal for:

  • • Day hikers prioritizing comfort and agility
  • • Lightweight backpackers with moderate loads
  • • Trail runners seeking more ankle support
  • • Hikers in wet climates requiring waterproofing
  • • Those wanting immediate usability without break-in

Not suitable for:

  • • Heavy backpackers carrying 40+ pound loads
  • • Hikers prioritizing maximum durability
  • • Those with very wide or high-volume feet
  • • Serious mountaineering or technical climbing
  • • Winter hiking in harsh conditions

Frequently Asked Questions

Are Salomon X Ultra 4 Mid Gore Tex boots true to size?

No, the X Ultra 4 Mid Gore Tex runs approximately half a size large and tends toward a narrow fit. Based on extensive user feedback and my personal testing, I recommend ordering 0.5 size smaller than your regular athletic shoe size. If you have wide feet, consider ordering your regular size or looking into the wide version. The narrow fit has been consistently reported across multiple platforms, so factor this into your sizing decision. Always try them on with the socks you plan to hike in, and consider the return policy when ordering online.

How long do X Ultra 4 Mid Gore Tex boots typically last?

Based on my 500+ mile testing and community feedback, the X Ultra 4 Mid Gore Tex boots show significant wear between 300-500 miles of use. The lightweight construction prioritizes performance over longevity. The Contagrip outsole performs exceptionally well initially but wears faster than traditional rubber compounds. Upper materials begin showing wear around 200 miles with more noticeable deterioration by 400 miles. While this is less than traditional leather boots, the performance benefits may justify more frequent replacement for many hikers. Proper care and avoiding extremely rocky terrain can help extend their lifespan.

Can I use X Ultra 4 Mid Gore Tex for winter hiking?

The X Ultra 4 Mid Gore Tex can handle mild winter conditions but isn't designed for serious winter hiking. They lack insulation for cold temperatures and the tread pattern, while excellent for three-season use, isn't aggressive enough for snow and ice traction. I've successfully used them in light snow and near-freezing temperatures, but they require additional traction devices for icy conditions. For serious winter hiking, consider insulated boots with more aggressive tread patterns. However, they excel in spring and fall conditions where you might encounter mixed weather and occasional snow patches.

What's the difference between X Ultra 4 Mid and low-cut versions?

The mid-height version provides additional ankle coverage and support compared to the low-cut model. The mid version offers better protection from debris, rocks, and brush, while the collar provides light ankle support without restricting natural movement. The mid version is slightly heavier but offers more versatility for varied terrain. I found the mid version more comfortable due to better tongue padding and ankle collar design. The waterproof membrane extends higher in the mid version, providing better protection during creek crossings and wet conditions. Choose the mid version if you prioritize ankle protection and don't mind the minimal weight increase.

Are these boots suitable for backpacking with heavy loads?

The X Ultra 4 Mid Gore Tex is best suited for lightweight backpacking with loads under 40 pounds. The flexible construction and moderate stack height prioritize agility over heavy-duty support. During my testing with a 35-pound pack, I experienced some foot fatigue on rocky terrain where a stiffer sole would have provided better support. For loads over 40 pounds or multi-day trips on rough terrain, consider more robust boots with stiffer construction. However, for weekend backpacking with moderate loads on established trails, they perform excellently and the weight savings can be significant over long distances.

How do I care for and maintain X Ultra 4 Mid Gore Tex boots?

Proper maintenance can extend the life of your X Ultra 4 Mid Gore Tex boots significantly. After each hike, remove debris and rinse with clean water, allowing them to air dry away from direct heat. Clean the Gore-Tex membrane monthly with specialized cleaners to maintain breathability and waterproofing. The poly-coated leather benefits from occasional conditioning, but avoid over-conditioning which can affect breathability. Replace the insoles periodically for better comfort and hygiene. Store them in a cool, dry place with the laces loosened. Avoid exposure to extreme heat, petroleum products, and harsh chemicals. Consider waterproofing treatments annually, though the Gore-Tex membrane provides the primary water protection. Regular maintenance helps preserve both performance and appearance throughout their lifespan.

Conclusion

Final Verdict: A Game-Changer with Caveats

After extensive testing across diverse terrain and conditions, the x ultra 4 mid gore tex represents a paradigm shift in hiking footwear design. These boots successfully challenge the traditional trade-off between weight and performance, delivering trail running agility with mid-boot protection and support.

Exceptional Performance Where It Matters

The combination of 14-ounce weight, no break-in period, and superior traction makes these boots ideal for hikers prioritizing comfort and agility. The Gore-Tex waterproofing proved reliable throughout my testing, and the Advanced Chassis system provides remarkable stability for such a lightweight design.

Honest Assessment of Limitations

The trade-offs are real and significant. Reduced durability compared to traditional boots means more frequent replacement, and the lightweight construction limits heavy load carrying capacity. Quality control concerns and sizing inconsistencies add complexity to the buying decision.

My Personal Recommendation

If you're a day hiker, lightweight backpacker, or trail runner seeking more ankle support, the X Ultra 4 Mid Gore Tex deserves serious consideration. The immediate comfort, exceptional traction, and waterproof reliability make them outstanding performers for their intended use cases.

However, if you prioritize maximum durability, carry heavy loads regularly, or need boots for harsh winter conditions, explore more robust alternatives. The key is matching your footwear choice to your specific hiking style and priorities.
